This is maybe the tightest, most well balanced racer I've ever played. I keep booting it up no matter how frustrated I get with it, it really is just that fun.

Firstly, it runs buttery smooth. Most well optimized UE5 game I've ever seen. It's pretty and vivid and colorful and a joy to look at. All on my 1660 SUPER?? 

Secondly, doing well in races requires that you, well, race well. The items obviously give you a boost when youre behind, but I always have to make sure Im hitting my lines if Im actually going to catch up to the head of the pack. I don't think bagging without thinking is gonna get you on the podium, at least in my experience. 

There's definitely a meta forming around certain gadget combos, but I've seen SO MANY viable builds that it doesnt feel like theres a "correct" waya to play online, which is really nice. It lets me experiment and play to different vibes without worrying about my rating taking a hit!

I havent experienced the Online issues others seem to be talking about. Theres a stray Communication error here and there but no more or less than Id expect from any other game? It was kinda bad at launch, but the situations definitely improved. Its a BIT annoying not being able to play World Race while a Festival is going on. Thats not a very big complaint tho, considering how quickly you can get all the festival rewards, you dont have to engage with it much if you dont want to. 

My only real complaint, and this is really just a factor of luck, but sometimes you can get stuck in a rubberbanding void that kind of dooms you to not be able to place well in a race. I know its just the way the cards fall sometimes, but when matchmaking seems to be skill based, it can really frustrating when youre just stuck coming in like 8th all the time bc youre locked in a position that will only ever give you white wisps.

All in all though, excellent game! Cant wait to see what characters the rest of next year brings! (Super looking forward to NiGHTS!!!!)

Let's get this out of the way first: this is easily the most fun racing game I have ever played. The core gameplay is fun, chaotic, yet also very rewarding of player skill, even if you don't experiment too deeply with the Gadget system. The item balance can sometimes be a bit much, but I didn't find it to be too bad.
The tracks are all fun, the CrossWorld gimmick adds a very good level of variety to every single race, and the unique character interactions are perfect for a huge Sonic fan like myself. The game offers a decent ammount of different modes, and the soundtrack is fantastic.
The game is, however, lacking in a couple of areas.
The most obvious one that everyone points out: the DLC characters don't have any voice acting. While understandable for some, it really is especially baffling that this was left out for characters such as Joker or Ichiban, though it's not enough for me to be a deal breaker. The servers when playing online races can also be quite iffy, with disconnects and network errors being something you will see a lot. Sometimes you'll go hours without seeing one, and other times you'll get 5 in a row, it's really odd. 
Now, while the game has a bunch of stuff for the player to unlock, and can definitely keep you busy in that regard, the game is honestly lacking in terms of single-player content, especially when compared to the previous two Sonic Racing titles. Despite being the most expensive game in the series so far, the only real gameplay variety in this game outside of the standard Grand Prix and Time Trial is the different modes in Race Park. While they are fun, they pale in comparison to what the previous games offered, yes, even the first All-Stars Racing. All-Stars Racing had Mission Mode, Transformed had World Tour and Team Sonic Racing had Team Adventure. All three of these - but in particular World Tour and Team Adventure - did an EXCELLENT job of offering a ton of single-player content, while also having very good variety, especially World Tour. So many different game modes that actually felt very different to one another, and were fun in their own right. Unfortunately, CrossWorlds does not have anything of the sort. The closest you'll get is the Race Park modes, which is a real shame, and even a little disappointing. 
With all that said, you may notice that despite this, I easily have the most playtime on CrossWorlds, and I'm still giving it a Recommended. Yeah, the core gameplay really is THAT fun. What the game lacks in single-player offerings, it MORE than makes up for by, as I stated right at the very start, being the most fun racing game I have ever played. It's also a little easier to swallow when the game at least tries to make the most of the "standard" racing game modes, offering a more in-depth Rival system in Grand Prix, and offering actual rewards for Time Trials to entice even the people who would normally never bat an eye at it to give it a try. It also has the most varied character roster and track selection in the series, at least when it comes to Sonic, easily eclipsing whatever Team Sonic Racing was trying to do.
Even if you're not a Sonic fan, you're bound to have a ton of fun with this game - it's really good!

I was really afraid we were going to have another Team Sonic Racing, but this game defied all my expectations for a Sonic game. I can't believe how fun this game is.


Alright, let's start with the good:


It takes almost all the good features from Team Sonic Racing: The cool cars, custom paint kits, custom horns, characters, certain tracks, and trashed bad features like the awful story mode, always being on a forced team, and abusing Team Ultimates by constantly swapping items with your team, or [i] locking paint kits behind awful mini-games that require an absolutely perfect performance or you don't get anything. [/i] This is very refreshing and shows that the dev team clearly understood what was good and bad about Team Sonic Racing. One of the most important things I look for in games these days is recognizing a development team wants to ACTUALLY make a game and not corporate slop, cutscene slop, nostalgia slop, etc.

Right from the start, we have a lengthy timeline of free content. They are communicating to the player-base that there will be plenty of content to keep players coming back and they are trying their best to convince consumers to accept the steep price of $70 for a base game. There's also lots to do in the game like the Grand Prix, but no terrible story mode this time. Then there's the Race Park, where you have a lot of modes to choose from that provides variety. My favorite from Race Park is Extreme Match, where all items on the track are the most powerful items in the game and since everyone has crazy items, there's less of a chance that you'll get bagged by the CPU. The race park also features the team racing from Team Sonic Racing and solo racing events. And of course there's time trials, and they are super challenging this time around. It's very satisfying to break records.

The character rival interactions are very charming and add depth to characters that haven't seen exploration in decades.

The gadget system is outstanding. The way it works is that you have a plate that you can upgrade over time to put more gadgets into to give yourself extra abilities during races. There's all sorts of combinations of upgrades you can pick from and it is clearly fine-tuned to ensure that there is not a superior strategy that would cause every other gadget set to be inferior and not worth trying out. However, there is a specific set I see being used online quite a lot used by top players, but that gadget set and vehicle loadout doesn't guarantee you'll win races. If you're curious, the loadout gives you invulnerability for a few seconds if you're able to get your drift meter to level 4, but other players can SEE your loadout and vehicle before a race and they will bum-rush you because they know what you're trying to do.

Then they replaced the in-game currency of Mod Pods with Donpa Tickets. In my opinion, you unlock every part in Team Sonic Racing way too fast because the game overrewarded you and it doesn't feel satisfying to get all the parts. Donpa Tickets elongate this process and make it feel rewarding to unlock things, but I'll expound on this later when I start talking about the bad parts of the game.

There's also the festivals that occur every two or three weeks where you can race online to unlock more free content. Unlike the Crash Team Racing Nitro-Fueled events, you simply unlock things from playing. You don't need Donpa Tickets for unlocking Festival items, but the Festivals ARE time-limited. I'm unsure what the dev team will do for people that missed Festivals, but I really hope it's not future microtransactions to purchase things you missed. That's what most games would do. Oh yeah, there's absolutely NO monetization. [i] Yet. [/i]

The modding community is bustling and incredible. While there are no plans I've heard for official extensive skin customization, like in CTR:NF, there are so many great skin mods to customize your characters, music, and even track pallettes with.


Now unfortunately, this is a Sonic game, so here's the bad:


My main concern, and I'm sure most of the player-base agrees, is that the grind for Donpa Tickets is [b] absurd. [/b] Most races you'll get about 14-16 tickets, and the parts can go up to 200 tickets. Doesn't sound too bad, right? But then each decal is 200 tickets and there's 30+ purchasable decals, each individual horn this time are 500 tickets, and there's 20+ horns. The auras for cars are 2000 tickets, but thankfully there's only just a few. [spoiler]After you finish the entirety of the base game Grand Prix, you get access to a friendship menu where you can get cool titles, decals for your car, and AI skins. But this is where you start realizing you're gonna need to grind tickets for DAYS. There's seven tiers for each character, and to max out friendship for just one character you need [i] 50,000 tickets. [/i] This virtually impossible goal clearly looks like a scheme for the game to introduce real-life currency purchasing in the future, and are not being upfront about it to keep people from abandoning the game.[/spoiler]

While the base game character interactions clearly have a ton of love put into them, almost all extra and future characters have absolutely no interactions and they don't even have voices. It's really lazy.

If you're on the grind for Donpa Tickets, you'll quickly find out that you're finishing most of the in-game achievements from constantly doing Grand Prix, Race Park, Time Trials, etc. Before you know it, the ticket grind becomes fake longevity where you're mindlessly grinding Donpa tickets because of the crazy high ticket prices, starved for content and waiting for the next Festival to occur.

Online connectivity is relatively fine, but online is really unstable at times and you'll get booted out of races for all sorts of reasons and that can be really frustrating at times. Speaking of online frustrations, festivals are exclusively online so the pro of free content becomes a con to people with unstable internet. Furthermore, certain auras and gadgets, AKA more free content, is locked behind an online ranking system. I understand that this is a way to encourage players to play online to get cool stuff, but again - what if someone just doesn't have internet? What if someone was barely able to download the game and has terrible internet connectivity? This puts these players at an unfair disadvantage that they can't control. What's worse is that some of the best gadgets come from online play.

Well I'm looking back at my review and I see I put more good than bad, so this game is probably worth your time. But please wait for a sale. This game is NOT worth $70.

I've played numerous Sonic / SEGA racing games before. And while I still think All Star Racing Transformed is still the best in the series, Crossworld is a close second!

What makes this game great is its crossworld gimmick. Because every races has a 2nd lap which "crosses" between different track, it makes each racing experience different, keeping it fresh & exciting!

While the game doesn't have a single player campaign like the other games, there's still plenty of things to do in Crossworlds. You can compete in Grand Prix mode (which has PLENTY of cups to go through), play some custom races via Race Park, or beat your best times in time trial. All of these modes has progression thanks to the in-game challenges, which rewards you with achievements and sometimes donpa tickets.

And these dompa tickets are the main currency of unlocking all the different vehicle customization of the game, which is quite in-depth. There's a lot of vehicle parts you can mix and match, while being able to change colors and applying some decals.

One of the other best aspect of Crossworld is online mode. Thanks to it supporting cross platform between many consoles, the game is VERY active, with matches always being filled with players. I find Crossworlds to be THE definitive online experience to play not only by yourself, but also with friends! Unlike previous games, you can EASILY invite 3 other online friends to play in Race Park, or online matches. And while the races are always against everyone, occasionally there's festivals that run throughout a weekend, that pairs a group of players into teams of 3. And somehow, the teamwork aspect in this game is better executed then Team Sonic Racing lmao.

However, the reason why I don't consider Corssworld to be the best Sonic/SEGA racing game is because of its controls, music, and complexity of its mechanics. While Transformed has tighter controls, with advanced mechanics sprinkled on like boost stacking, all the while having an absolute BANGER of a soundtrack. Crossworld on the other hand, has controls can sometimes feel stiff, doesn't have enough technicality to REALLY further improve you racing abilities outside of making better turns or finding best paths. And I also find most of the music to be quite bad, espeically the final laps, which has these ANNOYING choirs that takes away from the experience. And to say an OST is bad is a TRAVESTY to utter out in a Sonic game!

Overall, I still have a great time with Crossworlds. With its fun & addicting gameplay, and good amount of content to keep me entertained, even in solo. I wouldn't say its worth the full price, unless you're a die hard fan of Sonic or SEGA racing games. On sale though, I'd say it's worth picking up!

[h1] After the last Sonic Racing title was a mediocre mess, Sonic Racing CrossWorlds has stepped it up considerably. Granted with a few issues that could be ironed out later. [/h1]

[h2] From the outset, this game has extremely good arcade racer controls similar to previous entries [/h2] with nuances to learn and adapt to as you race with tracks readily taking advantage with tight corners and a wide variety of shortcuts to plan and look out for.

[h2] Laps 1, 2, and 3 are all different from each other. [/h2] Laps 1 and 3 take place on the same track albeit lap three will always have some differences to ramp it up with new shortcuts, hazards, and increased rings for maxing out that speed-o-meter. Lap 2 is where the signature CrossWorlds gimmick comes to play, every race will give the leading player two tracks to pick and race on. This helps add some uncertainty and leave every match different from the last.

[h2] Adding on is a feature that definitely shines just as much as the CrossWorld gimmick is the Gadget system, [/h2] allowing different sets of unique buffs to alter the way you play. From simple stat increases to allowing you to turn your drift boost to be invincible and last longer with an additional level. These can change the outcome of a race and makes it worthwhile to experiment in casual and experienced settings.

[h2] The player base will definitely last a good amount of time [/h2] and fill up lobbies with a consistent update schedule to come back to for in-game events and Cross platform support.

[h2] Network issues can sporadically happen, [/h2] disconnecting you from races, and will hopefully be ironed out as the game's lifespan goes on.

[h2] The crossovers with different IPs are underwhelming in most extents. [/h2] Characters expected to talk or at least grunt will be mute and only have their home media's SFX to accompany them when emoting. Which leads to them feeling lifeless compared to the base cast which is voiced pretty ok for the most part. Emotes commonly don't align in art style compared to others in the base roster. They also don't interact with any of the game's single player's features like rivals or friendships which again is disappointing. So no, you won't be seeing Miku interact with Spongebob.

[h2] Speaking of, this game visually is pretty meh. [/h2] UI doesn't have much style aside from the emotes, and can come off bland or in some cases poor quality. Race tracks can look good in some scenarios but have obvious muddy textures or lacking modelling. It's definitely not too bad but should be better for a 70$ title.  

[h2] Vehicle customization is good but could be better. [/h2] The main issues being the lack of tools like mirroring decals for symmetrical designs, changing the decal's material to be different from the body of the vehicle, or copying an existing decal to use again. The next being that decals are arbitrary limited in use by having them unable to stack on top of each other by a bounding box, only having EIGHT slots, and having spots on cars that just can't have decals over them. This may be a lack of time to expand the feature or most likely, fear of player's voice in what they can depict on their vehicles. Despite the crippling limitations however, players have still creatively used these to create unique looking cars for better or for worse. (How did they manage to depict 9/11)???

These issues [b] COULD [/b] be fixed later down the road, but mods are safe and readily available to improve or alter the visuals and sounds of the games.

[h2] Overall, I think this is a game that should be gotten on sale. [/h2] Given that if you want ALL of the non-Sega crossover content you'll have to shell out 30 dollars for the season pass alone.

Sonic Racing Crossworlds is a fine successor to Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed, which is still one of the best kart racers ever released. But if you're not in withdrawal because you can't find online matches in that game anymore, or you're not already a die-hard fan of the Sonic franchise, then I can only recommend this game if it's been discounted below your country's standard AAA price.

I say this mainly because this game's singleplayer offering does not at all compare to that of S&ART. Grand Prix and Time Trials, two fairly standard offerings for a racing game, are the only dedicated offline components. There is also the Race Park - which comes the closest to the unique objective-based gamemodes that were jam-packed into S&ART's World Tour - but that's best enjoyed with multiple people, and the modes offered within are generally insignificant team-based variations on regular races. What's especially odd is that many of the custom modes - and even some in-game unlockables - are exclusively available through online, the former only playable during "Festival" events. In other words, this is very much a multiplayer-first game.

One aspect in which Crossworlds does lap S&ART is in both its gameplay and cosmetic customisation. The highlight here is the "Gadgets" system: perks that give you (tangible) special benefits on the track, such as improved boosting or being able to manipulate item odds. Some gadgets are clearly better than others and there is a "meta" in place, but nevertheless I had a lot of fun experimenting with gadget builds in the Race Park. You're also able to mish-mash car parts together within predefined vehicle classes; but while picking and choosing won't significantly alter your stats, I'd say that's to the game's benefit, since it lets you prioritise cosmetic expression over perfect min-maxxing. Although this game could do with additional gadget slots (the five that are available quickly didn't cut it for me) and a way to more easily configure a preset combination of gadgets, character and vehicle.

SR:C loosely copies over the "Transformed" concept from S&ART, in which your vehicle seamlessly transforms between a car, boat and plane when dictated to do so by the track. The cars are the obvious highlight here: in land mode, each of the five vehicle classes control notably different from one another and are all very reactive/responsive in their own way (except maybe the Power vehicles with their [i]awful[/i] handling). I'd go as far to say that this controls much tighter than S&ART did; but I wouldn't say the same for the boat and the plane. Both of these remove traditional drifting in favour of a charge jump and a charge boost respectively, which actually decrease the control you have over your vehicle. While a well-timed charge jump rewards you with rings (which increase your top speed), the plane's charge boost (which is supposed to funnel rings towards you) has far more situational use. The omission of "risk boosting" in air mode is also rather glaring. It all serves to make the implementation of the Transformed mechanic, a highlight of the previous game, appear as more of a boring afterthought.

If you're looking for an affordable singleplayer kart racing experience, I'd recommend [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/212480/]S&ART[/url] instead. Yes, even thirteen years later. But if you're looking for a great kart racer with multiplayer staying power, then this game is your best bet. The promise of at least a year of post-launch updates, and occassional Festival events themed around the release of new characters, seem to help keep the multiplayer waiting times short. Honestly, that was my only expectation going into this game: a new take on S&ART with the benefit of an active online playerbase. It's been thoroughly met.

After 300 hours, it's safe to say that Sonic racing is back and better than ever. Cross worlds does a great job filling in the blanks for previous entries in the Sonic racing series; from the visuals to the roster to how satisfying and exciting it is to race and control oneself, this game thoroughly outdoes its predecessors. Compared to Mario Kart World this game does lack that extreme technical Flair that Sonic is known for, which is ironic since one of these series is known for rail grinding and wall running and it isn't the one that includes these techniques in their latest cart racer entry. This doesn't necessarily hold the game back, neither visually or mechanically; there is plenty to master within the game that will keep your hands busy as well as feeding the eyes with satisfying visual feedback. As someone who preferred Mario Kart before we were customizing vehicle part options, the 180 I've turned about on vehicle customization as a result of this game through its gadgets and combining parts of vehicles to min max stats and equally importantly, the appearance of the vehicle, is worth studying. There are several different types of vehicles, one type for each type of stat: speed, power, acceleration, handling, and boost. If you know anything about Sonic Riders you may have noticed that all of the Boost machines are the Sonic series own hoverboards, known as extreme gear. We have not been able to use these hoverboards in a good game since 2006, so seeing them here is fantastic even if they do not function the way Sonic Riders functioned as a game.  



The other equally important part of customization is the gadget system. Gadgets and the plates you slot them into, are unlocked as you continue to play the game. Some gadgets require that you play online to unlock them, but there isn't a large amount of those in the game and the ones that are there aren't particularly earth-shattering anyway. The gadgets affects rain from adding a few ticks into a stat you particularly like to causing your character to be in a constant Spin Attack State like f-zero while drifting. The amount of skill expression and player expression on offer through the gadget system is Bar None for a Kart Racer and maybe even for racing games in general. You are given five different Gadget plates to work with. My friendly rival races with gadgets that allow them to get ahead of the pack early by increasing their speed through ring acquisition and making him difficult to move from his path with power types in power vehicles while I prefer to add a fourth level of drift boost for Speed and invincibility on  extreme gear making me as fragile as I am agile if I'm not careful. These play styles are nothing alike, yet all are present within the game and can be mixed and matched.





The game's music is phenomenal and matches the vibe of the stages which also look very good. Aside from the opening theme the game's music either remixes tracks from earlier parts of Sonic's history makes new tracks for new stages or via unlocks in time trials, has rips directly from previous entries. You would be hard-pressed to find a track in the game that genuinely sounds bad and it happens to be lap 3 of dragon Road. Speaking of which, each track, even the crosswords, have lap 3 variants that up the tempo and intensity accompanying your race to the Finish. Certain tracks even become completely different songs related to the initial song from lap 1 creating an intense and dynamic final lap experience that Mario Kart has yet to deliver. Though, the sheer density and quality of Mario Kart worlds tracklist is easy to argue as better than crosswords, but we're comparing a 9 and 10.


So, what's the bad? For starters $70 is crazy For a game who's DLC isn't even voiced outside of Hatsune Miku.  The online connection is serviceable, usually getting you into matches pretty quickly with little hiccups. However, the game struggles to retain connectivity between players who have queued up for the games only random matchmaking mode, Ranked, as a group of 2 to 4 players. The game will almost as often as it succeeds, fail to keep all of the players in one group connected for more than a few races, giving one or two players a communication error with frustrating frequency. It's even worse when not playing the ranked mode. Past a certain point getting players to be able to join a Lobby is its own struggle because the connection will either time out over and over as a player tries to join or players will be dropped at random from the lobby. Had I not received this game for $60 I would be a little more outraged.

The balance of the gadgets is mostly fine, though there are some standouts above the rest. In ranked, I am above the 8000 ELO mark and noticed but before even reaching the 4,000 mark The Meta of the game had been solved down to two or three different Gadget combinations; but, there are many different fun and viable builds even if a couple stand out as the best. That's okay.

Onto the topic of items, the balance for them isnt great even if its better than mario karts in alot of places. "Slime" signals a warp ring over all the users opponents for a short time frame before dropping green goop on all of them, causing them to spin out, drop all of their items, and splotch slime all over their screen. The slime on their screen also slows the racer down for as long as it remains. Like all items that signal a warp ring over your head, this can be dodged with a Boost Wisp (the mushroom equivalent), a Shield, or a Tornado on reaction. This is far better design than unreactable instant lightning, but it affecting players behind you too is a little absurd. Im unsure why we need an item like this, nor why we're going for something so generic. The slicer is a generic shuriken that you can get in any position lower than 1st it seems, and it cuts the back half of a players vehicle, making them drop one item and lose an intense amount of speed temporarily.It's a super red shell.  this item is capable of being drawn when in 9 through 12th Place. You never want to pull this item in the positions that you are likely to get it and getting hit by this item is always miserable, making it one of two items I think have grounds for removal entirely. The second of which, drops a weight on first and second that flattens and makes them drop an item. This is effectively a projectile mega mushroom that not only locks onto two players from anywhere on the map, but also is effectively a blue shell as it targets the player in first. This combined with the existence of King boom boo, the actual blue shell in the game provides us with a game that has two blue shells and three Global means to affect the first place player from anywhere. The fact that the items are so uninspired and generic is part of what pushed me away from All Stars Racing. Stuff like the slicer and slime make the game feel as unsonic as they look. I'll even say they could have just textured the Slime to be purple and we would have all said it's the goop from chemical plant I get it! But they couldn't even do that. Couldn't Sharah from Secret Rings have casted a fire ring around us instead of the generic tornado? Couldn't we have used any of the shields throughout Sonic's series instead of the generic literal Shield? What was wrong with using other attacking wisps?

As I approach the 3,000 word mark, I realize I may have said far too much. Though Im mostly okay with that given how passionate I am about this game and how much it has to offer despite its flaws. These flaws do not stop it from being a fun game but they do stop it from being a complete game so it's hard to justify buying this game for $70. It has always felt as though Sonic racing games with the exclusion of riders have felt very cheaply put together and somewhat soulless for the last decade and a half there about. If you can find this game for ~60 you will arguably be getting your money's worth. A must have.

It's a fun video game that actually resists to the player (although sometimes a bit unfairly so), boasts good optimisation considering it's made with Unreal Engine, it's loaded with references and interactions that'll make Sonic fans smile, and manages to be a fresh addition to the kart-racing genre.

Customisation can also go pretty far, giving players tons of room to heavily change their playstyle by providing both vehicle parts and perks to mess around with and try to make different builds.

This does imply that characters are essentially just skins though. Playing as Sonic, Knuckles, Dr. Eggman or Silver doesn't have any bearings on how your races will play out. "Types" are tied to the vehicles, although what they do is more of a passive thing as they do not grant active skills like in Riders.

I do also wish extreme gears were more than just a different type of skin for the vehicle, because they handle exactly the same as anything with wheels in this game, which is frankly a shame considering many of us wanted a new Riders game. This doesn't play like one at all.

The music is pretty good (although maybe a bit [i]too[/i] high energy which is saying something considering this is a kart racing game), although I'm having trouble recalling certain themes, which is a first for me in a Sonic game personally. It usually sticks to me instantly.

The audio mixing is all over the place though, very often the music gets drown out in the mess of sound effects and voice clips, and even the way the music itself is mixed doesn't help it stand out, whereas this was never an issue in Mario Kart games. This might explain why I'm having trouble remembering what the music sounds like. The remixes of themes such as Radical Highway or Dragon Road are really cool though.

The voice acting ranges from decent to pretty great in the English version. The French version is actually quite good too, but relies way too much on the English translation for its script, only going "off-track" when literal translations wouldn't work.

I appreciate that a lot of the stuff that is usually implicit in other kart racers (how much drifting is required to get a boost, how long we must hold the acceleration button to get a fast start, etc) is shown in great detail here. If you fail at these things, it literally is a skill issue on your part.

We can also bind everything to our liking, which is great as I prefer to accelerate with the right trigger instead of a face button.

Local multiplayer is an absolute blast and also counts towards your overall progression, so you always have a reason to play offline. I haven't tested online play yet.

The game runs great on the Steam Deck provided you use medium-quality graphics. Just don't use the highest anti-aliasing parameter and you should be hitting 60 FPS consistently.

I was extremely hyped for CrossWorlds, after playing both the Open Network Test (ONT) and the demo. However, the full release disappointed me in a multitude of ways. I do not recommend buying this game at full price. I believe it should be thirty dollars, forty at most, and should've released in a much more finished state than it currently is in.

My issues are as follows: 

Terrible netplay (Playing with 4 players in your squad seems to be nearly impossible. I don't know if it's a crossplay issue, a network issue, or just the game, but it NEEDS to be fixed. I literally cannot play with more than 3 players, and even then, I can barely play with three. Two is also a challenge, with me or the other person getting disconnected every few matches, or sometimes even after every single match.)

Unfinished game state (There are a lot of notable bugs. The game also completely lacks a story mode, unlike in the previous Sonic racing game, Team Sonic Racing. You may think this doesn't matter much, but given the fact that Dodon Pa is back in this game, and characters make various comments about him/about the race tracks that elude to a story being present, it is extremely strange that there is zero story mode/story-adjacent modes in this game. You get to the credits after beating every Grand Prix, much like Mario Kart or other such games. It feels very unrewarding, as someone who expected more. There are also VERY FEW voicelines for every character, with each character repeating the same voiceline over twelve times per race in my estimate, and with some characters, such as the Werehog, not even having a voice at all. This is also extremely disappointing to me. Especially since the Werehog is the pre-order bonus, causing me to feel ripped off, in a way. I paid for the Digital Deluxe version of this game. I did have high hopes for it, and I did expect it to be good.)

Terrible jukebox implementation (I am VERY passionate about music. This game pissed me off with the way they implemented the jukebox; you can only set playlists as custom tracks for each lap, NOT individual songs, and the only way to really get individual songs is to "favorite" a song, which even then, you can only have ONE playlist of "favorite songs", making it extremely tedious to get any sort of order in your jukebox usage. For example, if you wanted to listen to the original Metal Harbor song on Metal Harbor, you would have to favorite Metal Harbor from the SA2 soundtrack, then set your "favorites" playlist as the BGM for a lap. But if you have ANY other songs than just Metal Harbor, it'll screw it up and cycle through all the songs in the playlist randomly/shuffled instead. You cannot choose songs individually. You cannot choose songs specifically, either. Also, you can only unlock songs from doing Time Trials, which I find incredibly annoying as someone who doesn't enjoy that game mode in the slightest. I feel as if there is a very big missed opportunity to implement a shop system, one where you can spend your Dodon Pa Tickets to buy tracks, gadgets, ETC, but that just doesn't exist in the game. ALSO, you cannot even rewind, skip, or pause jukebox songs. It is overall terribly implemented and should've been handled with much more care.)

Lack of game modes (It's very, very straightforward what you can do currently. Either go offline to play Time Trials, Grand Prix, or Race Park, or go online to play World Match or Friend Match. Friend Match is an issue in itself. It is unfortunately the only online gamemode that won't disconnect you every 5 seconds, which seriously shouldn't be the case, but it is. This means that, if you want to have a smooth experience in online multiplayer, you are forced to play in a custom lobby, most likely with bots filling in for the 8 or so extra friends you probably don't have on standby. Worst of all, you have the option to enable Rival Teams in this mode, but only the HOST will be able to receive the vehicle rewards for beating the rival teams, which pretty much defeats the point of doing it for anyone else in the lobby. Why did SEGA make the game like this?)

Timed DLC (This is more of a personal issue. But, the fact that we have to wait for DLC characters & stages to come out, some for MONTHS, it just makes the game feel like it isn't even ready to be released yet. I know that maybe to some this is just seen as a marketing strategy, or a way to build up hype, but to me, it comes across as lazily delivered content that isn't ready for release and should've been kept in the oven longer.)

Overall, I am really enjoying Sonic Racing CrossWorlds after overcoming my initial huge, blaring problems with it, as well as accustoming myself to the gameplay style, and getting cosmetic mods to make the game less disappointing, but that long list of requirements I just listed should NOT be essential for enjoying the game. You should be able to enjoy it right out of the box, no? 

I think that Sonic Racing CrossWorlds could be an amazing game, if it were given longer to be developed, and had a bit more thought put into it. There is clearly a lot of ambition within this project, and a lot they aimed to achieve, but it ultimately falls flat in some crucial ways that are, frankly, hard to recover from. I sincerely hope it will get updates that fix all of my issues with it; that is my biggest hope for now.

OK HOLD ON! It's a good game. Like it's fundamentally a good game, I think. But in my opinion, it's plagued by the lack of polishing and no one is talking about it. The price/content ratio is not great.

The game is fun, the base stuff you expect from a karting game is good: the amount of vehicles, the roster, the tracks (really good tracks), etc. The crossworld gimmick is fine but you'll realize it's a bit forgettable although it gives you an incentive to be first before 2nd lap so you get to choose the crossworld you want. I like the same stuff as other people do.

But it feels unfinished for everything that's outside of gameplay. Now don't get me wrong: what the game offers is fine. But for that price tag? No, it absolutely doesn't. Let me give you a list of what is wrong in this game:

- The progression system
The game has a very boring and uninspired progression system. Most unlockables are through using the in-game currency. Gears, decals, wheels, everything. There is zero incentive to play other characters, other types of cars, or do particular things like using a certain gadget or achieving anything in particular. There's so many cars and characters, it's daunting to try all of them and the game doesn't have any milestones or incentives for that. Only content unlocked outside of that is the AI racers' cars that you unlock through beating the racers.
There's a friendship system that gives you character specific rewards (decal of that character, etc.) and you become friends... by giving them tickets. Which is SO boring (and kinda weird when you think about it).

- The game has no skins.
For $70, I simply don't like that. Extreme gears are finally back and characters don't even have their Riders skin. But we have that awful AI skin (an edgy monochromous recolor), I guess so a skin system in the game is already there. I find it baffling that the AI skin is what we got. It's just the worst set of cosmetics ever imo. They have no voices, just cyberized grunts and I can't recommend downloading the cyberized AI voices mod enough. It gives AI racers their original voice with a robot filter. It's stunning work. Skins could have been friendship unlockables or rewards for playing with extreme gears (for Riders costumes for example). Having so many cars but no skins just doesn't sit right with me, I'm sorry. Not at that price. In the era of cosmetics in video games, releasing a game that could have so many cosmetics feels like a huge fumble especially when you look at Sonic mobile games that are literal museums of unlockable skins for free.

- The voice acting philosophy
One of the few issues people mentioned: DLC characters aren't voiced, not even Sega characters. There's no justification for this. I have no reason to play Joker if he doesn't say anything. You could just reskin any DLC with a mod for free since they don't speak. Even Werehog has no voice. Like, please. This is so unacceptable for that price. Also, they spent so much time on the rivalry thing with the voice lines and the banter but I didn't feel it was that impactful. It's very corny and it doesn't happen online. It's an offline feature in Grand Prix. However, characters only have very few grunts and it's SO irritating. When you trick, characters always do the exact same grunt or say the same thing 100% of the time. You trick 50 times per race, you hear the same shit 50 times per race. It's so irritating to the point there were mods day one to mute that. Some characters have very irritating voice lines like Rouge. Sonic goes "good good good good, good nice, good, good nice" omg SHUT UP!

- The BGM can't be assigned to stages.
You can unlock so many songs from so many earlier games but they only work in a playlist. You make a playlist and each song will be assigned to each lap regardless of the stage. You can't assign a song to a stage. Completely pointless.

- The offline content is too light.
 You have the Grand Prix, the park with some challenges but nothing crazy really. No real solo mode and it looks like a game that's made mostly for the online, but...

- The online mode has NOTHING either.  
You just join a lobby, do one race (you can vote out of three + one random track among the three options), you play it and it's over. Thanks for playing! It's not a Grand Prix, there's no way to use the different gadgets to adapt to your opponent throughout the course of a GP like in offline. Oh that track? I'll use that build! Oh my opponents are playing a certain build, maybe I should take something else to adapt. No, doesn't exist. It's one track and you don't get to change your gadgets to the track because the track is selected once the race is starting. It's just one random race for fun and that's it. Also, another detail, when you finish the race, you don't see the time for completion. It's such a staple in racing games and yet...
There's an endorsement system but you can only endorse a player (teammate or opponent)... before the race. Not after. What's the point? There are also emotes to say "hi!", "bye", "no!", "yes!", "oh!" but they can only be used in the lobby. Again, what's the point? Why would I say "YES!" in a lobby with no chat anyway? However, playing online grants good rewards like auras and unique gadgets and it's a very good incentive.
Servers flop all the time. You get disconnected very often but this will hopefully be fixed.

- World Match is disabled during events.
It lasts three days so it's alright I guess, but people don't like it. Don't force stuff like that on people. Also the rewards for Hatsune's festival are just stickers and a honk. It's just giving free battlepass on a mobile game. At least give her one outfit or something, those work so much better. However, Festival is really fun imo, it makes the competition less redundant and I hope to see tweaks to regular races like that more often. You don't need to solely rely on being first place to win.

- The tutorial is garbage and lacking.
It's a racing game so there's nothing crazy about the game works but the tutorial is a bunch of little GIFs with a caption. As a teacher, I find this type of tutorial really ass for new players because you don't get to practice in a race. You have to memorize THEN play. Also we still don't know what stats are fully about. Sadly, there's a ton I don't like about this game. It's still fun to play with friends, but - for such a high price - this game is a letdown. That being said, let me focus on the negatives:

-----

** Audio **

Sound effects suck. They are noisy as hell, and there is no background ambience. Muting the music results in a dead silent main menu, which is just extremely lazy. Putting together a basic stereo background audio asset for a company that certainly already has a huge audio library shouldn't even take an hour...

The music is a repetitive mess. Though the main theme and its main motif are catchy, all music feels over-hyped, with a ton of it sounding like 16-bar loops that a music student put together in a bedroom studio...

** AI Players **

Why are high-level "Rival" AIs essentially cheating the game? Couldn't the devs simply design AI that's genuinely challenging without having to resort to cheats? Playing against AI feels... cheap as hell.

"Rival" AIs recover from hits extremely fast, seem to be speed up to unreasonable speeds to catch up when left behind, and drive over off-bounds areas (e.g. grass) boost-less without any sort of penalty (e.g. slowing down). Also, non-"Rival" AIs seem to NEVER target the "Rival" AI - they often hold onto their items and slam them on me as soon as I'm between them and the "Rival" AI.

** Menu Flow **

The menu is not the worst - don't get me wrong - but there are issues with the NUX (New User Experience) in this game. I have friends over for dinner and games every now and then. The first time we played, it took us 2 hours to figure out how to add gadgets to the gadget cards - then, randomly after some Cup, a tutorial notification popped up teaching us how to do it... lmao.

** Characters **

Why do all characters sound annoying af? They all behave and sound like 12-year-olds trying to play it cool. That in itself is not a problem - but why all of them? Can we also address the ultra-expensive DLC characters that are just dead-silent? Take Joker (Persona 5), for example: SEGA could've literally just supplied some voice lines from the Persona 5 game and called it a day - but they didn't even do that, which is a f-ing joke. In fact, for the asked price, the least they could've done is hired alt voice actors for a few voice lines...
